title: BoE closer to forcing capital build-up
text:
European rivals threaten UK universities 
The committee decided “on balance” not to raise the CCB above 0 per cent but said it would review this at the end of the year after regular bank stress tests are over. 
“The committee also noted the possible benefits of moving the CCB in smaller increments, especially when credit growth was not unusually strong and given the likely lags behind in implementation of any new CCB rate,” the minutes published on Thursday read. 
Banks already set aside capital in line with European and international rules. They complain that increasing demands weigh on their profits and therefore their ability to lend; regulators and policymakers say the rules are necessary to reduce the likelihood of taxpayer bailouts. 
In January, the biggest lenders must start to set aside ‎extra capital. 
The minutes also reveal the extent of BoE contingency planning earlier this summer as it worried about whether Greece would crash out of the eurozone ‎. 
It decided not to publish the details earlier in case markets took fright. 
Now it has been revealed that the UK central bank increased its monitoring of deposits and liquidity at Greek and Cypriot bank branches and subsidiaries in Britain, and asked about contingency planning at the UK’s big banks. Related Topics
